quizzes.title: History Quiz: Trenton and Time
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, title, trenton. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which king of England is not the title character of a Shakespearean play?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Henry VII

questions.question: In what year was the Dutch Labour Party (S.D.A.P.) founded?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1894

questions.question: What was the connection between Mary Stuart (Queen of Scots) and Bloody Mary (Queen of England)?

options.text: Mary Stuarts grandmother, Margaret Tudor, was an aunt of the English Mary.
Bloody Mary had the Scottish Mary beheaded
They were both daughters of Henry VIII (but had different mothers).

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mary Stuarts grandmother, Margaret Tudor, was an aunt of the English Mary.

questions.question: Who became the first female Cabinet minister of Holland in 1956?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Margarita Klompe

questions.question: In the Netherlands, who headed the famous postwar Cabinet of 1948 - 1958?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: William Drees

questions.question: Which great journey was funded by an English king?

options.text: Ferdinand Magellans round trip around the world (1519-1521)
Christopher Columbuss to the West Indies (1492)

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Giovanni Cabotos to Newfoundland (1497)

questions.question: The commander of the Hessian Garrison during the Battle of Trenton was taken to Philadelphia where he was questioned by the Congress on January 7th, 1777.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: The Battle of Trenton lasted over three hours.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: What period of time during the Eighty Years War (1568- 1648) is referred to as the Twelve Years Truce?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1609 to 1621

questions.question: Holland means what in the ancient Dutch language?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Land of  wood

questions.question: Was there a second battle in the town of Trenton on January 17, 1777?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: No

questions.question: At the time of the Battle of Trenton, some Hessians were quartered in a stone building that is now a Trenton museum. What is the name of this museum?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Old Barracks Museum

questions.question: What Batavian led the ill-fated uprising against the Romans AD 69-70?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Claudius Civilis

questions.question: At the time of the Battle of Trenton, the Hessian garrison numbered some 1500 men. Twenty soldiers were killed and eighty wounded. About how many soldiers were taken prisoner?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 900

questions.question: What were Washingtons passwords for the crossing of the Delaware River and the attack on Trenton?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Victory or Death

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Decade and James
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, globe, symphony. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who can be regarded as the only military dictator of England?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oliver Cromwell

questions.question: What decade saw the the end of the Enlightenment, the invention of canned food, and the publishing of the atomic theory?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1800s

questions.question: The House of Windsor was founded by King George V in 1917 when he changed the name of his family to Windsor. What was the original name of his family?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: German

questions.question: What decade was nicknamed the Mauve Decade, and saw the discovery of the X-rays by Wilhelm Rontgen?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1890s

questions.question: Where did Scotland unsuccessfully try to establish a colony?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Panama

questions.question: During this decade the first modern railway opened, and Beethovens Ninth Symphony premiered in Vienna.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1820s

questions.question: Who or what destroyed the Great Spanish Armada in 1588?

options.text: A hurricane off the coast of Ireland
Francis Drakes attack in the English Channel

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A hurricane off the coast of Ireland

questions.question: What decade witnessed the publishing of Charles Darwins The Origin of Species, and the first official game of baseball?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1850s

questions.question: The prototype telephone, the light bulb and the phonograph were all invented during this decade.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1870s

questions.question: What was the last successful foreign invasion of Britain?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dutch in 1688

questions.question: What was the connection between James I of England and James VI of Scotland?

options.text: Their boyish fight at St Andrews University sparked a war that eventually led to the unification of Scotland and England.
James I was the great-grandfather of James VI.
They were both illegitimate sons of Elisabeth I.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They were the same person.

questions.question: Mark Twain published Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, and Robert Louis Stevenson published Treasure Island and The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde during this decade.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1880s

questions.question: This decade saw the end of the Napoleonic Wars in Europe and the Year Without a Summer.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1810s

questions.question: Shakespeares theater, The Globe, was destroyed by fire in 1613. Which Queen saw its reopening?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Elisabeth II

questions.question: When James, brother of king Charles II, married Mary of Modena, who was Catholic, the English Parliament wanted James to do what?

options.text: Renounce his rights to the English throne
Force her to become Anglican or Presbyterian
Abstain from having sex with his wife

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Abstain from having sex with his wife

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Attila and Hun
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, headquarters, world. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: In 5th century AD, a child hostage exchange was arranged, to keep peace between the Huns and the Romans.  Attila, future king of the Huns was sent to the Roman court in exchange for which Roman hostage?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Flavius Aetius

questions.question: In 453, Attila the Hun died in his room on the night of his wedding to which woman?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ildico

questions.question: What was the relationship between Attila and Bleda who ruled the Huns together until 445?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They were brothers

questions.question: Where was the assault rifle invented?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: in Italy

questions.question: Honoria, sister of the Roman Emperor, broke the peaceful relations between Rome and Attila the Hun  by trying to do what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Marry Attila

questions.question: In 452, this influential Roman Pope participated in the negotiations with the Huns near Mantua and dissuaded Attila the Hun from devastating Rome.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pope Leo I

questions.question: In World War I, the machine gun combined with this invention was responsible for most of the battle casualties.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Gliddens invention

questions.question: Attila the Huns palace and headquarters in Europe were situated on the territory of which modern country?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hungary

questions.question: During this decade the submarine was invented, Alfred Nobel invented dynamite, and the American Civil War broke.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1860s

questions.question: In 451, Flavius Aëtius, in alliance with the Visigoths, finally defeated Attila the Hun. Where did the famous battle take place?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: On the Catalaunian Fields

questions.question: To form an alliance against Attilas Huns, in 451 the Romans combined armies with which Visigoth leader?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Theodoric I

questions.question: In this Germanic legend, turned into an operatic tetralogy by Richard Wagner, Attila the Hun appears by the name Etzel.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Song of the Nibelungen

questions.question: Because of the plundering and devastations across Europe, Attila the Hun came to be called by what nickname?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Scourge of God

questions.question: This decade saw the first postage stamp, the first electrical telegraph and the first use of general anesthesia in an operation.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1840s

questions.question: He said: If you want to make a lot of money, invent something that will enable Europeans to cut each others throats.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hiram Maxim

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Invention and Telegram
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, leader, truman. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which of these European nations did not come under Soviet domination in the five years following the end of World War Two?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Yugoslavia

questions.question: In 1946 George Kennan, a Russian specialist in the US embassy in Moscow, sent a long telegram to Washington. His telegram was very persuasive and is given much credit for the US adopting this kind of policy.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: policy of containment

questions.question: Which of the following was invented by Hiram Maxim?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The silencer

questions.question: The Marshall Plan of 1947 offered massive economic aid to help war-devastated nations in Europe. However, communist controlled Eastern Europe received none of the aid for what reason?

options.text: The US Congress stipulated that no aid could be given to communist nations.
Western European nations refused to participate in the plan if Eastern European communist nations were included.
The Soviet dictator Stalin refused to allow any communist controlled nation of Eastern Europe to receive Marshall Plan aid
War damage in Eastern Europe was relatively small.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Soviet dictator Stalin refused to allow any communist controlled nation of Eastern Europe to receive Marshall Plan aid

questions.question: What was the main purpose of the Truman Doctrine, that was first announced in 1947?

options.text: US support for the United Nations Organization for maintaining world peace
keeping the US isolated from conflicts in Europe and Asia
economic aid to European allies and Japan

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: containment of communism

questions.question: The operational jet fighter was invented during this war.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: World War II

questions.question: Who did Soviet leader Joseph Stalin appoint as his successor before his death in 1953?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nobody

questions.question: When was the first automatic revolver produced?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Between 1901 and 1903

questions.question: Why did President Truman relieve General MacArthur of command of UN forces in the Korean War?

options.text: because MacArthur wanted to withdraw all UN forces below the 38th parallel in Korea
because MacArthur publicly criticized his commander-in-chiefs (President Trumans) policy of limited war in Korea
because MacArthur refused to allow bombing attacks on communist bases in China
because MacArthur advocated counterattacking communist forces in Europe to relieve pressure on Korea

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: because MacArthur publicly criticized his commander-in-chiefs (President Trumans) policy of limited war in Korea

questions.question: Which is the odd one out?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dragon

questions.question: In what year was the first mass produced multishot pistol patented?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1835

questions.question: He was responsible for the invention of the caterpillar tractor, which was the basis of the tank.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James B. Hill

questions.question: Although it  looks a lot like the World War II bazooka, the US Army Javelin anti-armor weapon has this advantage over other weapons of its type.

options.text: It is only 50% the weight of similar weapons.
It is about 50% the cost of similar weapons.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It leaves no heat  trail.

questions.question: Why is the Borchardt pistol of 1893 considered an important invention?

options.text: It was the first pistol to have a separate ammo magazine.
It was the first pistol approved for use by the Swiss Guard to help guard the Pope.
It was the first pistol that was not made of metal.
It was the first pistol to have an effective range of over 60 yards.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It was the first pistol to have a separate ammo magazine.

questions.question: When was a telescopic sight first put on a rifle?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1880

quizzes.title: History Quiz: World War and Shrapnel
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, shrapnel, june. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What two Japanese carriers attacked the Aleutian islands on June 3rd 1942?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Junyo and Ryujo

questions.question: What European nation received US aid  to try to put down the communist insurgency in Indochina in the late 1940s and early 1950s?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: France

questions.question: Which of these were known as Stalins Organs?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Katyusha Rocket Launchers

questions.question: Where did General Mark Wayne Clark die?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Charleston, South Carolina, USA

questions.question: How long did the United States keep the monopoly on the atomic bomb?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: four years until 1949

questions.question: How many Americans were killed in the capture of Makin Atoll in 1943?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 66

questions.question: Name the military alliance made up of the Soviet Union and the communist nations of Eastern Europe.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Warsaw Pact

questions.question: For a few years in the mid-1950s relations between the Soviet Union and the United States became less tense.  What is this period of time called?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: the thaw

questions.question: Which of the following is the best reason why the KMT (Nationalists) under Chiang Kai-shek were defeated by the communists in the civil war following World War Two and forced to flee to Taiwan in 1949?

options.text: The only support for the KMT was from Chinese peasants.
The US refused to give any aid to the KMT.
The communist forces greatly outnumbered the KTM and were better equipped.
There was much corruption and inefficiency in the KMT leadership.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: There was much corruption and inefficiency in the KMT leadership.

questions.question: Who developed the deadly V-2 combat rocket during World War II and where was it built?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Werner von Braun, Nordhausen

questions.question: What general was killed by shrapnel in the Battle of Okinawa in 1945?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: General Simon Buckner, Jr.

questions.question: Where did Joseph Goebbels, one of Hitlers closest associates, earned his PH.D.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Heidelberg University

questions.question: What was the nickname of the Italian Royal Army officer who led military expeditions in Africa during World War II?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: the Butcher of Ethiopia

questions.question: What two US Presidents served during the first decade of the Cold War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Truman, Eisenhower

questions.question: Who was in charge of the 1st Polish Independent Parachute Brigade during operation Market Garden?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Major General Sosabowski

quizzes.title: History Quiz: People and Cuba
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, people, eyebrows. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: It was believed in the Middle Ages that dilated pupils are infinitely enchanting. To dilate their pupils people used the juice of this plant as eye drops.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Belladonna

questions.question: In the Middle Ages, the large forehead was considered a sign of grandeur and wisdom thats why people used this common method to enlarge their foreheads.

options.text: They shaved off a strip of hear above the forehead.
They bleached the hairline above the forehead.
They plucked the hair above their forehead.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They plucked the hair above their forehead.

questions.question: These marks were a huge craze in the Middle Ages.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Moles

questions.question: When did the Cuban Missile Crisis occur?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: October 1962

questions.question: For medieval people beauty marks had very special meanings. Which of these statements is true?

options.text: Beauty marks above the lip meant coquetry.
Beauty marks around the eyes meant passion.
Beauty marks on the forehead meant grandeur.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: The US  became convinced that Soviet nuclear missiles were in Cuba by which of the following?

options.text: photos taken by a U-2 spy plane
a Cuban defectors report and pictures of missiles sites
Soviet announcement of the instillation of nuclear missiles in Cuba

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: photos taken by a U-2 spy plane

questions.question: Which of the following is true about medieval makeup?

options.text: Makeup was very heavy and greasy and clogged the skin pores.
Both men and women used makeup.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: Medieval people had very weird tastes when it came to eyebrows. Artificial eyebrows made from this material were in fashion.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mouse skin

questions.question: What did people do in medieval times to make their skin appear more translucent?

options.text: They painted blood vessels on their skin.
They used medications to enlarge their blood vessels.
They made cuts in their skin.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They painted blood vessels on their skin.

questions.question: Who were the leaders of the US and the Soviet Union during the Cuban Missile Crisis?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kennedy, Khrushchev

questions.question: During the Cold War, in the first week after discovering the nuclear missiles in Cuba, the US did which of the following?

options.text: debated with the Soviet Union in the United Nation concerning the legality of the nuclear missiles in Cuba
demanded immediate withdrawal of the missiles or the US would invade Cuba
threatened nuclear attack on the Soviet Union if the Soviet nuclear missiles were not removed from Cuba
made no public mention of the missiles in Cuba

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: made no public mention of the missiles in Cuba

questions.question: In the Middle Ages this type of complexion was very fashionable and everybody was trying to achieve it.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dead-pale white skin

questions.question: During the Dark Ages, this magical ingredient was put into creams because it helped people achieve the desired complexion.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lead

questions.question: During the Cuban Missile Crisis, the US President and his advisors ultimately decided that their best immediate response to the Soviet nuclear missiles in Cuba would be to blockade Cuba. Why did they think this was the best decision?

options.text: Stronger measures such as bombing the missile sites could later be used if the blockade failed.
The US had superior naval and military power in the Caribbean area.
A blockade was less likely to risk nuclear war than other options under consideration.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: This hair color was very fashionable in medieval times. Women applied special mixtures to their hair and stayed in the sunlight for hours to achieve it.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Venetian blonde
